week3.practice1_html:
```html

Toby, your shedding is still worsening just ~2 months after COVID and over-trainingâ€”classic early â€œonset â†’ peakâ€ window. Right now your sleep is under 5h, meals low in protein, and your body is under repair stress. A solid, protein-rich breakfast is the big domino: it calms morning cortisol, anchors circadian rhythm after rough nights, and feeds follicles with the amino acids they need so stabilization can arrive sooner and regrowth isnâ€™t delayed. ğŸŒ±

What to do

  • Eat within 60â€“90 min of waking
  • Include at least 25â€“30 g of protein (keeps cortisol steadier)
  • Add colorful plants (antioxidants buffer post-illness inflammation)
  • Keep it simple & fast so you donâ€™t skip on busy mornings

Your plan

  • Omnivore quickie: 2 eggs + Greek yogurt cup + berries
  • Vegan quickie: Protein smoothie (soy/pea protein, banana, spinach, flax)
  • Batch-prep overnight oats with protein powder to remove decision fatigue
  • Pair with glass of water + 5 min light exposure by a window to anchor circadian rhythm

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Set your alarm 15 min earlier so breakfast isnâ€™t rushed after nights of broken sleep.
  2. Pre-pack smoothie ingredients in freezer bags so your half-awake self just blends.
  3. Use your phone timer to remind you to actually eat vs. doom-scroll past the window.
  4. Limit caffeine until after breakfast (push that â€œafter 3 pmâ€ habit earlier too).
  5. Follow meal with a few deep breaths or stretchâ€”signals safety to your nervous system.

Why this works (for you)

  • Protein-rich mornings flatten the big cortisol swings worsened by <5h sleep, reducing telogen push.
  • Because your illness was in Sept, shedding may peak into Nov; feeding follicles daily shortens time-to-stabilization and nudges regrowth into its usual 3â€“4 mo window.
  • Early balanced fuel steadies mood/anxiety, lowering the doom-scroll stress loop that fragments your nights.
  • Iron and amino acids in these options build hemoglobin and keratin substrates critical for regrowth once shedding stabilizes.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: Skipping breakfast or loading pastries only â†’ likely more fatigue, unstable blood sugar, extended shedding curve.
  • Green lights: Within 7â€“10 days, steadier mid-morning energy; less jittery caffeine need; fewer doom-scroll spirals before bed.
  • You donâ€™t need perfectionâ€”just show up most mornings. Every protein start is a tiny vote for regrowth â¤ï¸
```

week3.practice2_html:
Toby, your body is still in the peak shedding phaseâ€”hair loss is worsening from the July over-exercise and September illness. Low protein intake, spotty nutrition, and late meals before short nights are keeping your system from moving into stabilization. The â€œplate tweakâ€ is your big domino here: giving your follicles the raw materials (protein, iron, omegaâ€‘3s) to shorten the lag and set up regrowth once shedding slows. ğŸŒ±

What to do

  • Aim for protein at all 3 meals (20â€“30 g each)
  • Add omegaâ€‘3 source 2â€“3x/week (salmon, sardines, chia, or flax)
  • Build ironâ€‘rich plates with beans, spinach, lentils, lean meats
  • Pair plants + vitamin C (peppers, citrus) to absorb iron better
  • Shift your last meal a bit earlier (2â€“3 hrs before bed) for deeper sleep

Your plan

  • Breakfast (anchor): Greek yogurt parfait with berries + chia
  • Lunch: Lentil & spinach soup + slice of wholeâ€‘grain toast
  • Dinner: Grilled salmon, quinoa, roasted broccoli
  • If late hunger hits: small protein snack (boiled egg, edamame) instead of a full meal

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Start tomorrow with a proteinâ€‘forward breakfast (â‰¥25 g).
  2. Batch cook 1â€“2 iron/omegaâ€‘3 rich meals on Sunday to reduce weeknight friction.
  3. Keep vitamin C fruit/veg handyâ€”add them wherever you eat beans/greens.
  4. Set a â€œlast biteâ€ cutoff ~2 hrs before intended sleep; prep a lighter snack option if needed.
  5. If late caffeine cravings strike, sub green tea (earlier) or herbal tea (after 3 pm).

Why this works (for you)

  • Because sleep is <5 hrs/night, deeper nutrition helps blunt cortisol and preserves protein stores that hair needs while your sleep stabilizes.
  • Your peak shedding (~Sepâ€“Oct) reflects lag from July + illness. Adequate protein/iron shortens timeâ€‘toâ€‘stabilization so regrowth can begin on schedule.
  • Irregular periods suggest possible iron riskâ€”even without heavy flow. This plan cushions that gap safely with food.
  • Earlier meals = steadier night melatonin â†’ more repair signals to roots.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: skipping meals or relying on coffee as breakfast â†’ intensifies shedding pressure; gently reset the next meal to include protein.
  • Green lights: within ~10â€“14 days, you notice (1) less intense handfuls in shower, (2) energy more stable through the day, (3) fewer night wakings after earlier dinners.
  • Progress may feel slow, but each balanced plate is a vote toward regrowth. Youâ€™re building the floor your follicles need. â¤ï¸
week3.practice3_html:
Toby, your shedding is still in the worsening phase because the fever illness is ongoing and sleep is so short (<5h). Right now your body is in "cortisol survival mode." Adding the right fats is a big dominoâ€”EPA/DHA-rich omegaâ€‘3s calm inflammation from illness stress and give your follicles raw material to reâ€‘enter growth once stability lands. Think of this as priming the soil while your body fights through the storm ğŸŒ±.

What to do

  • Aim for 2â€“3 portions of fatty fish (salmon, sardines, mackerel) per weekâ€”or algae oil if plantâ€‘based.
  • If supplementing, choose triglycerideâ€‘form, refrigerated fish oil; avoid capsules that smell "fishy" (sign of rancidity).
  • Balance: look for combined EPA + DHA, at least 500â€“1000 mg total per day.
  • Cut back on processed seed oils (corn, soybean, sunflower)â€”they tilt inflammation the wrong way.

Your plan

  • Anchor omegaâ€‘3 foods at least 3x in the week ahead.
  • Pair with protein (important since you usually only hit 1 highâ€‘protein meal/day).
  • Keep fats earlier than 1h before bed to ease digestion with your late dinners.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Write down three meals this week where you can swap in salmon, tuna, or sardines instead of chicken/noodles.
  2. If that feels too heavy, add 1â€“2 tsp ground flax or chia to breakfast until fish feels doable.
  3. Buy small packs of frozen fish; keeps fresher if you're only eating 1â€“2 portions a week.
  4. Take supplements with the first meal of the day, not at night (helps stomach, avoids reflux at bedtime).
  5. When doomâ€‘scrolling urges pop up at night, prep tomorrowâ€™s protein+fat meal insteadâ€”small shift, big ripple â¤ï¸.

Why this works (for you)

  • Omegaâ€‘3s dampen fever/illnessâ€‘driven inflammation â†’ fewer follicles pushed into rest, helping shed stabilize faster.
  • Because your overâ€‘exercise trigger has resolved, nutrition now distinguishes whether you enter stabilization by month 3â€“4 or stay shedding longer.
  • Pairing fats with protein covers two weak spots (youâ€™re low on both) â†’ fuels regrowth signals once shedding levels out.
  • Late meals + short sleep keep cortisol high; eating clean fats earlier in the evening softens that curve.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: Fish oil burps, nausea, or very loose stools â†’ reduce dose, split into 2 smaller servings.
  • Green lights: Within 1â€“2 weeks: smoother skin, less hair static/frizz, digestion calmer after rich meals.
  • Remember, your shedding may not stop instantlyâ€”but these fats are laying down brickwork for the regrowth start phase thatâ€™s waiting on stability. Stay the course âœ¨.
